a.definition: The first letter of the alphabet; used as an indefinite article
examples: A cat sat on the mat

b.definition: The second letter of the alphabet
examples: The letter B comes after A

c.definition: The third letter of the alphabet

d.definition: The fourth letter of the alphabet

e.definition: The fifth letter of the alphabet; most common letter in English

f.definition: The sixth letter of the alphabet

g.definition: The seventh letter of the alphabet

h.definition: The eighth letter of the alphabet

i.definition: The ninth letter of the alphabet; used as a pronoun for oneself

j.definition: The tenth letter of the alphabet

k.definition: The eleventh letter of the alphabet

l.definition: The twelfth letter of the alphabet

m.definition: The thirteenth letter of the alphabet

n.definition: The fourteenth letter of the alphabet

o.definition: The fifteenth letter of the alphabet; used as an exclamation

p.definition: The sixteenth letter of the alphabet

q.definition: The seventeenth letter of the alphabet
examples: Q is usually followed by U

r.definition: The eighteenth letter of the alphabet

s.definition: The nineteenth letter of the alphabet

t.definition: The twentieth letter of the alphabet

u.definition: The twenty-first letter of the alphabet

v.definition: The twenty-second letter of the alphabet

w.definition: The twenty-third letter of the alphabet

x.definition: The twenty-fourth letter of the alphabet

y.definition: The twenty-fifth letter of the alphabet; used to ask questions

z.definition: The twenty-sixth and final letter of the alphabet

algorithm.definition: A process or set of rules to be followed in calculations or other problem-solving operations
examples: The sorting algorithm efficiently organized the data
Machine learning algorithms can recognize patterns
algorithm.etymology: From Arabic al-Khwarizmi, named after the 9th-century mathematician

quantum.definition: The minimum amount of any physical entity involved in an interaction
examples: Quantum mechanics describes the behavior of matter at atomic scales
A quantum of light is called a photon

artificial.definition: Made or produced by human beings rather than occurring naturally
examples: Artificial intelligence mimics human cognitive functions
The artificial flowers looked surprisingly real

intelligence.definition: The ability to acquire and apply knowledge and skills
examples: Her intelligence was evident in her quick problem-solving

computer.definition: An electronic device for storing and processing data
examples: The computer processed the data in seconds

programming.definition: The process of creating a set of instructions that tell a computer how to perform a task
examples: Programming requires logical thinking and attention to detail
She learned programming to build her own website

database.definition: A structured set of data held in a computer
examples: The database stores customer information securely
We need to update the database with new records

network.definition: A group of interconnected computers or systems
examples: The office network allows file sharing between computers

software.definition: Computer programs and operating information used by a computer
examples: The software update fixed several bugs
We need new software for project management

technology.definition: The application of scientific knowledge for practical purposes
examples: Technology has transformed how we communicate
The latest technology makes tasks more efficient

mathematics.definition: The abstract science of number, quantity, and space
examples: Mathematics is the language of science
mathematics.etymology: From Greek mathematikos meaning 'fond of learning'

philosophy.definition: The study of the fundamental nature of knowledge, reality, and existence
examples: Ancient Greek philosophy laid the foundation for Western thought
His philosophy of life emphasized compassion
philosophy.etymology: From Greek philosophia meaning 'love of wisdom'

science.definition: The intellectual and practical activity encompassing the systematic study of the structure and behavior of the physical and natural world
examples: Science has revolutionized our understanding of the universe
Computer science combines mathematics and engineering

knowledge.definition: Facts, information, and skills acquired through experience or education
examples: She has extensive knowledge of ancient history

learning.definition: The acquisition of knowledge or skills through study, experience, or being taught
examples: Machine learning enables computers to improve automatically

education.definition: The process of receiving or giving systematic instruction
examples: Education is the foundation of progress
She received her education at Harvard University

experience.definition: Practical contact with and observation of facts or events
examples: She has years of experience in marketing

understanding.definition: The ability to understand something; comprehension
examples: His understanding of physics is impressive
We need better understanding between cultures

wisdom.definition: The quality of having experience, knowledge, and good judgment

creativity.definition: The use of imagination or original ideas to create something
examples: Creativity is essential in art and design
The project required a lot of creativity

innovation.definition: The action or process of innovating; a new method, idea, or product
examples: The company is known for its innovation

invention.definition: The action of inventing something; a thing invented
examples: The invention of the wheel changed civilization
Her latest invention could revolutionize medicine

discovery.definition: The action or process of finding or learning something for the first time
examples: The discovery of penicillin saved millions of lives
Scientific discovery requires patience and persistence

research.definition: The systematic investigation into and study of materials and sources
examples: Medical research has led to many breakthroughs
She conducts research on climate change

analysis.definition: Detailed examination of the elements or structure of something
examples: Data analysis is crucial for business decisions

synthesis.definition: The combination of ideas to form a theory or system
examples: The synthesis of different viewpoints led to a solution

hypothesis.definition: A supposition or proposed explanation made on the basis of limited evidence
examples: The scientist tested her hypothesis through experiments
We need more data to support this hypothesis

theory.definition: A supposition or system of ideas intended to explain something
examples: Einstein's theory of relativity changed physics
The theory explains the observed phenomena

principle.definition: A fundamental truth or proposition that serves as the foundation for a system of belief
examples: The principle of equality is fundamental to democracy

concept.definition: An abstract idea or general notion
examples: The concept of time is difficult to define

idea.definition: A thought or suggestion as to a possible course of action
examples: The idea came to him suddenly

thought.definition: An idea or opinion produced by thinking
examples: Deep thought is required for this problem
What are your thoughts on this matter?

thinking.definition: The process of using one's mind to consider or reason about something
examples: Critical thinking is an important skill
His thinking on this issue has evolved

reasoning.definition: The action of thinking about something in a logical, sensible way

logic.definition: Reasoning conducted or assessed according to strict principles of validity
examples: There's no logic in his argument

rational.definition: Based on or in accordance with reason or logic
examples: We need a rational approach to this problem

reasonable.definition: Having sound judgment; fair and sensible

sensible.definition: Chosen in accordance with wisdom or prudence; likely to be of benefit
examples: It would be sensible to save money

practical.definition: Of or concerned with the actual doing or use of something rather than with theory
examples: We need practical solutions to these problems
She has practical experience in engineering

useful.definition: Able to be used for a practical purpose or in several ways
examples: The information was useful for our research

helpful.definition: Giving or ready to give help

beneficial.definition: Resulting in good; favorable or advantageous
examples: The changes were beneficial to the company

advantageous.definition: Involving or creating favorable circumstances that increase the chances of success
examples: The location is advantageous for business
It would be advantageous to start early
Weather conditions are favorable for sailing

positive.definition: Consisting in or characterized by the presence or possession of features or qualities

negative.definition: Consisting in or characterized by the absence rather than the presence of distinguishing features

optimistic.definition: Hopeful and confident about the future

pessimistic.definition: Tending to see the worst aspect of things or believe that the worst will happen

confident.definition: Feeling or showing confidence in oneself; self-assured

certain.definition: Known for sure; established beyond doubt

sure.definition: Completely confident that one is right
examples: I'm sure this is the right way

definite.definition: Clearly stated or decided; not vague or doubtful

clear.definition: Easy to perceive, understand, or interpret; not confused or doubtful
examples: It's clear that we need to change

obvious.definition: Easily perceived or understood; clear, self-evident, or apparent

evident.definition: Clearly revealed to the mind or the senses or judgment

examples: The cause of the problem is apparent
The treasure was hidden in the cave

secret.definition: Kept hidden from others; not known or seen by others

public.definition: Of or concerning the people as a whole
examples: The park is open to the public

private.definition: Belonging to or for the use of one particular person or group of people only
examples: We need to have a private conversation

personal.definition: Belonging to or affecting a particular person rather than anyone else

individual.definition: Single; separate; existing as a distinct entity

separate.definition: Forming or viewed as a unit apart or by itself
examples: Keep the documents in separate files

together.definition: With each other; in unity or proximity

united.definition: Joined together politically, for a common purpose, or by common feelings

joint.definition: Shared, held, or made by two or more people together
examples: They opened a joint bank account

shared.definition: Used, done, or experienced jointly with another or others

common.definition: Occurring, found, or done often; prevalent

usual.definition: Habitually or typically occurring or done; customary
examples: He arrived at the usual time

normal.definition: Conforming to a standard; usual, typical, or expected

typical.definition: Having the distinctive qualities of a particular type of person or thing
examples: This is typical behavior for him
A typical day at the office

standard.definition: Used or accepted as normal or average

regular.definition: Arranged in or constituting a constant or definite pattern

consistent.definition: Acting or done in the same way over time, especially so as to be fair or accurate

steady.definition: Firmly fixed, supported, or balanced; not shaking or moving

stable.definition: Not likely to change or fail; firmly established

secure.definition: Fixed or fastened so as not to give way, become loose, or be lost
examples: Make sure the door is secure

safe.definition: Protected from or not exposed to danger or risk; not likely to be harmed
examples: The children are safe at home
Is it safe to swim here?

dangerous.definition: Able or likely to cause harm or injury
examples: That road is dangerous at night
It's dangerous to text while driving

risky.definition: Full of the possibility of danger, failure, or loss

uncertain.definition: Not able to be relied on; not known or definite

skeptical.definition: Not easily convinced; having doubts or reservations

suspicious.definition: Having or showing a cautious distrust of someone or something
examples: She was suspicious of his behavior

trusting.definition: Showing or tending to have a belief in a person's honesty or sincerity

examples: She remained faithful to her principles

loyal.definition: Giving or showing firm and constant support or allegiance

dedicated.definition: Devoted to a task or purpose; having single-minded loyalty or integrity

committed.definition: Feeling dedication and loyalty to a cause, activity, or job

determined.definition: Having made a firm decision and being resolved not to change it

persistent.definition: Continuing firmly or obstinately in a course of action in spite of difficulty

tenacious.definition: Tending to keep a firm hold of something; clinging or adhering closely
examples: She has a tenacious grip on power
He's tenacious in pursuing his goals

stubborn.definition: Having or showing dogged determination not to change one's attitude
examples: He's too stubborn to admit he's wrong

flexible.definition: Capable of bending easily without breaking; willing to change or compromise

adaptable.definition: Able to adjust to new conditions

versatile.definition: Able to adapt or be adapted to many different functions or activities

talented.definition: Having a natural aptitude or skill for something

skilled.definition: Having or showing the knowledge, ability, or training to perform a task well

professional.definition: Relating to or belonging to a profession

competent.definition: Having the necessary ability, knowledge, or skill to do something successfully

capable.definition: Having the ability, fitness, or quality necessary to do or achieve a specified thing

able.definition: Having the power, skill, means, or opportunity to do something
examples: She's able to solve complex problems

qualified.definition: Officially recognized as being trained to perform a particular job

experienced.definition: Having knowledge or skill in a particular area gained over time

informed.definition: Having or showing knowledge of a particular subject or situation
examples: Keep me informed of any changes

educated.definition: Having been educated to a high standard
examples: He comes from an educated family

intelligent.definition: Having or showing intelligence, especially of a high level

smart.definition: Having or showing a quick-witted intelligence

clever.definition: Quick to understand, learn, and devise or apply ideas; intelligent

genius.definition: Exceptional intellectual or creative power or other natural ability
examples: She has a genius for mathematics

wonderful.definition: Inspiring delight, pleasure, or admiration; extremely good

amazing.definition: Causing great surprise or wonder; astonishing

impressive.definition: Evoking admiration through size, quality, or skill

striking.definition: Attracting attention by reason of being unusual, extreme, or prominent

notable.definition: Worthy of attention or notice; remarkable

significant.definition: Sufficiently great or important to be worthy of attention; noteworthy

important.definition: Of great significance or value; likely to have a profound effect on success

crucial.definition: Decisive or critical, especially in the success or failure of something

critical.definition: Having a decisive or crucial importance in the success or failure of something

necessary.definition: Required to be done, achieved, or present; needed

required.definition: Officially compulsory, or otherwise considered essential

optional.definition: Available to be chosen but not obligatory

voluntary.definition: Done, given, or acting of one's own free will

willing.definition: Ready, eager, or prepared to do something

ready.definition: In a suitable state for an activity, action, or situation; fully prepared

prepared.definition: Ready to do or deal with something
examples: She's well prepared for the exam

organized.definition: Arranged in a systematic way, especially on a large scale

systematic.definition: Done or acting according to a fixed plan or system; methodical
examples: He's very systematic in his work

methodical.definition: Done according to a systematic or established form of procedure

careful.definition: Making sure of avoiding potential danger, mishap, or harm; cautious

cautious.definition: Careful to avoid potential problems or dangers

prudent.definition: Acting with or showing care and thought for the future

wise.definition: Having or showing experience, knowledge, and good judgment

foolish.definition: Lacking good sense or judgment; unwise

silly.definition: Having or showing a lack of common sense or judgment; absurd and foolish

ridiculous.definition: Deserving or inviting derision or mockery; absurd

logical.definition: Of or according to the rules of logic or formal argument

illogical.definition: Lacking sense or clear, sound reasoning

unreasonable.definition: Not guided by or based on good sense

fair.definition: In accordance with the rules or standards; legitimate

unfair.definition: Not based on or behaving according to the principles of equality and justice

just.definition: Based on or behaving according to what is morally right and fair

unjust.definition: Not based on or behaving according to what is morally right and fair

examples: That's the right thing to do

correct.definition: Free from error; in accordance with fact or truth

incorrect.definition: Not in accordance with fact; wrong

precise.definition: Marked by exactness and accuracy of expression or detail

exact.definition: Not approximated in any way; precise

general.definition: Affecting or concerning all or most people or things; widespread

particular.definition: Used to single out an individual member of a specified group or class

special.definition: Better, greater, or otherwise different from what is usual

unique.definition: Being the only one of its kind; unlike anything else

distinctive.definition: Characteristic of one person or thing, and so serving to distinguish it from others

characteristic.definition: Typical of a particular person, place, or thing

representative.definition: Typical of a class, group, or body of opinion
examples: This is representative of his work

exemplary.definition: Serving as a desirable model; representing the best of its kind

perfect.definition: Having all the required or desirable elements, qualities, or characteristics

examples: We live in an imperfect world

flawed.definition: Having or characterized by a fundamental weakness or imperfection

complete.definition: Having all the necessary or appropriate parts

incomplete.definition: Not having all the necessary or appropriate parts

entire.definition: With no part left out; whole

total.definition: Comprising the whole number or amount

examples: This is only a partial solution

limited.definition: Restricted in size, amount, or extent; few, small, or short

unlimited.definition: Not limited or restricted in terms of number, quantity, or extent

infinite.definition: Limitless or endless in space, extent, or size; impossible to measure

endless.definition: Having or seeming to have no end or limit

eternal.definition: Lasting or existing forever; without end
examples: The eternal struggle between good and evil

temporary.definition: Lasting for only a limited period of time; not permanent

permanent.definition: Lasting or intended to last or remain unchanged indefinitely

lasting.definition: Enduring or able to endure over a long period of time

enduring.definition: Lasting over a long period of time

durable.definition: Able to withstand wear, pressure, or damage; hard-wearing

strong.definition: Having the power to move heavy weights or perform other physically demanding tasks

weak.definition: Lacking the power to perform physically demanding tasks
examples: She felt weak after the illness

mighty.definition: Possessing great and impressive power or strength

formidable.definition: Inspiring fear or respect through being impressively large, powerful, intense, or capable
